## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Interplanetary Shock
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-11-30T20:15:25Z
## Message ID: 20211130-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significant interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR at L1 at 2021-11-30T13:45Z. 

The event is still being analyzed. Strong magnetospheric compression and geomagnetic storm expected. 

Activity ID: 2021-11-30T13:45:00-IPS-001.

## Notes:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME update (ensemble) (STEREO B, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-11-30T13:43:25Z
## Message ID: 20211130-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2021-11-29T10:38:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20211129-AL-001). Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO B. For 48 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO B between about 2021-12-02T09:30Z and 2021-12-02T20:42Z (average arrival 2021-12-02T16:22Z) for 43% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2021-12-02T02:40Z and 2021-12-02T12:58Z (average arrival 2021-12-02T08:24Z) for 100% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 82% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-5 range (below minor to minor).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-11-29_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX104/20211129_103800_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX104_anim_tim-den.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-11-29_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX104/20211129_103800_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX104_arrival_Earth.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-11-29_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX104/20211129_103800_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX104_Earth_stack.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-11-29_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX104/20211129_103800_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX104_probabilistic_Kp_forecast_wdist.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-11-29_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX104/20211129_103800_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX104_arrival_STB.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-11-29_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX104/20211129_103800_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX104_STB_stack.gif

## Notes:
This CME event (2021-11-29T10:38:00-CME-001) is also predicted to have a potential impact to Solar Orbiter at 2021-12-02T12:12Z (plus minus 7 hours) based on previous heliospheric modeling (see notification 20211129-AL-001). 

Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2021-11-29_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX104/Detailed_results_20211129_103800_ncmes1_sims48_HILOX104.txt

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Solar Orbiter, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-11-29T15:11:00Z
## Message ID: 20211129-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2021-11-29T10:38Z.

Estimated speed: ~600 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 27 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -5/-19 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2021-11-29T10:38:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Solar Orbiter.  The leading edge of the CME will reach Solar Orbiter at 2021-12-02T12:12Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2021-12-02T10:55Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 3-5 (below minor to minor).
   
  
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2021-11-29T10:38:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20211129_154400_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20211129_154400_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20211129_154400_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20211129_154400_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_SolO_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

This CME is still being analyzed as more imagery becomes available.

SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2021-11-26T01:25Z.

Estimated speed: ~539 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 29 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -39/18 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2021-11-26T01:25:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect STEREO A and Solar Orbiter (glancing blow).  The leading edge of the CME will reach STEREO A at 2021-11-29T01:11Z and the flank of the CME may reach Solar Orbiter at 2021-11-29T12:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2021-11-29T11:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 2-3 (below minor).
   
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2021-11-26T01:25:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20211126_070000_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20211126_070000_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20211126_070000_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20211126_070000_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20211126_070000_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20211126_070000_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20211126_070000_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_SolO_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

This measurement was limited to coronagraph imagery from a single spacecraft (SOHO LASCO).  Although the source region is clear, the direction of material ejection from the associated filament eruption has uncertainty of up to 10 degrees.  This may influence the predicted arrival times (or potentially non-arrival) at Solar Orbiter and Missions near Earth.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-11-25T16:14:53Z
## Message ID: 20211125-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu starting at 2021-11-24T13:10Z. Energetic electron fluxes are currently below threshold but remain elevated.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed stream starting on 2021-11-20 (see notifications 20211123-AL-001, 20211123-AL-002).

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2021-11-23T16:40:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for November 17, 2021 - November 23, 2021
##
## Message Issue Date: 2021-11-24T19:10:21Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2021-11-17T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-11-23T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20211124-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares and only 3 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 4 occurred during the synoptic period of 2021-11-17T00:00Z-03:00Z. These slightly elevated values of Kp were associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2021-11-15 (see notification 20211115-AL-002).

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in Earth's outer radiation belt were elevated towards the end of the reporting period and crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu beginning at 2021-11-23T16:40Z (see notifications 20211123-AL-001 and 20211123-AL-002). The elevated energetic electron flux levels were associated to a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2021-11-20.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2021-11-18T13:48Z     ~551            C               127/2                 38                          SOHO                              
2021-11-20T06:12Z     ~894            C              -114/7                 10                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2021-11-21T22:12Z     ~515            C                90/13                27                          SOHO                              
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-11-24T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-11-30T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels for the upcoming week. There are currently three numbered Active Regions (12896, 12897, and 12898) on the Earth-facing disk, all of which have been quiet with minimal flaring activity throughout the reporting period. It is likely they will remain quiet throughout the outlook period as regions 12896 and 12897 rotate off of the Earth-facing disk by the end of the period. There are new regions emerging in the southern hemisphere of the Earth-facing disk that have not been numbered yet, but may become numbered Active Regions during the reporting period. There are at least two Active Regions on the western limb of the STEREO A facing disk near S30 and N20 that may rotate onto the Earth-facing disk by 2021-11-27.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week, but may become slightly elevated due to a small coronal hole centered around S10W10 on 2021-11-24 that may reach a geoeffective longitude starting late on 2021-11-27. 

## Notes:

ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2021-11-23T16:40Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream which arrived on 2021-11-20, reaching a maximum speed of approximately 698 km/s. The solar wind speed observed at L1 is currently around 510 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2021-11-23T16:40:00-RBE-001.

## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares and only two C-type CMEs (see details below). Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, the C-type CME initially observed in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2021-11-10T15:16Z was estimated to impact Mars at 2021-11-15T15:45Z and OSIRIS-REx at 2021-11-14T17:01Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20211110-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest level of Kp = 4 occurred during the synoptic periods from 2021-11-15T18:00Z to 2021-11-16T06:00Z. This elevated value of Kp was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-11-15 (see notification 20211115-AL-002). The solar wind speed reached values of 600 km/s by 2021-11-16 and has remained elevated.  The arrival of this coronal hole high speed stream was also previously detected by the IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments at STEREO A on 2021-11-14. 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu on 2021-11-13 (see notifications 20211113-AL-001, 20211113-AL-002, and 20211115-AL-001). This elevated energetic electron flux is likely due to the arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-11-09, which reached a maximum speed of approximately 468 km/s. However, the energetic electron fluxes were elevated prior to this observed threshold crossing due to the combined arrival of several CMEs at L1 (see notification 20211110-7D-001).

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-11-17T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-11-23T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the upcoming week. There are currently four numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing solar disk and all regions exhibit low magnetic complexity and may not produce too much activity in the upcoming period.  Active Regions 12894 and 12895 will rotate off of the Earth-facing disk during the first half of the outlook period. Near the end of the outlook period, Active Regions 12896 and 12897 may reach longitudes that are favorable for magnetic connectivity with Earth. One unnumbered Active Region rotated onto the STEREO A-facing disk (near latitude S25) around 2021-11-15 and may rotate onto the Earth-facing disk early in the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between minor to moderate levels during the outlook period. Currently, NASA missions near Earth are under the influence of the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-11-15 described above. Later on, a small coronal hole centered near S25E25 in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA may reach geoeffective longitudes on or around 2021-11-21.

## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for November 03, 2021 - November 09, 2021

## Report Coverage End Date: 2021-11-09T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20211110-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate levels during this reporting period with 1 M-class flare, 1 O-type CME, and 2 C-type CMEs (see details below).   The long-duration M2.0 class flare peaking at 2021-11-09T17:02Z possibly originated from Active Region 12891 (near N16W100 at the time of the flare) and was associated with the O-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2021-11-09T16:48Z (details below).  Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the flank of the CME may give a glancing blow to Mars at 2021-11-13T16:00Z and OSIRIS-REx at 2021-11-13T00:30Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20211109-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was at strong levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 7 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp = 7 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2021-11-03T21:00Z-2021-11-04T00:00Z and 2021-11-04T06:00Z-12:00Z (see notifications 20211104-AL-001 and 20211104-AL-002). These elevated values of Kp were associated with the possible combined arrival of the C-type CME first detected by STEREO A COR2 at 2021-11-01T18:38Z, C-type CME first detected by SOHO LASCO C2 at 2021-11-01T21:36Z, and the O-type CME first detected by SOHO LASCO C2 at 2021-11-02T02:48Z (see notification 20211103-AL-001) detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2021-11-03T19:23Z. Strong compression of the magnetosphere was detected following this arrival.  Simulations indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2021-11-03T21:29Z (see notifications 20211103-AL-003 and 20211103-AL-005).

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu beginning at 2021-11-04T10:50Z and remained elevated through the remainder of the reporting period (see notifications 20211104-AL-003, 20211104-AL-004, 20211106-AL-001, and 20211108-AL-001).  The elevated energetic electron flux levels were caused by the possible combined arrival of the CMEs mentioned above (see notification 20211103-AL-001).

The flux of > 10 MeV protons detected by GOES exceeded the 10 pfu threshold starting at 2021-11-03T20:55Z (see notifications 20211103-AL-002 and 20211103-AL-004).  Also, the flux of one or more of the > 15.8 MeV protons channels detected by SOHO were elevated, briefly exceeding the 10^(-1) pfu/MeV threshold, starting at 2021-11-03T20:17Z.  This solar energetic particle event was associated with the possible combined arrival of the CMEs mentioned above (see notification 20211103-AL-001).

The flux of 13-100 MeV protons detected by STEREO A remained elevated above background levels, but below the threshold of 10^(-1) pfu/MeV during the reporting period.  This elevated energetic proton flux level at STEREO A was caused by the C-type CME first seen by SOHO LASCO C2 at 2021-11-01T02:00Z (see notifications 20211101-AL-001 and 20211101-AL-002).

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate this week due to the solar energetic particle events and radiation belt enhancement described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-11-10T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-11-16T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be at minor levels for the upcoming week.  There are currently three Active Regions on the Earth-facing solar disk.  Active Regions 12893 (N16W47) and 12894 (S30E14) have a low magnetic complexity classification and may not produce too much activity as Active Region 12893 rotates off of the Earth-facing disk by 2021-11-13.  However, Active Region 12895 (N24E36) has been active during the reporting period resulting in two C-class flares.  It may be expected for this Active Region to continue producing some activity throughout the outlook period. Active Region 12891 (near N16W105 at the end of the reporting period), which produced the recent M2.0 class flare and associated O-type CME, may continue to produce more CME activity beyond the western limb of the Earth-facing disk.  One new Active Region rotated onto the STEREO A-facing disk (near latitude S20) on 2021-11-08, and may rotate onto the Earth-facing disk early in the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be at minor levels during the outlook period.  It may become slightly elevated around 2021-11-14 due to a small diffuse coronal hole seen around S30W25 on 2021-11-10.

## Summary:

Strong compression of the magnetosphere detected. Simulations carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center indicate that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma is close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2021-11-03T21:29Z.

The activity is associated with the combined arrival of the C-type CME with ID 2021-11-01T18:38:00-CME-001 and the O-type CME with ID 2021-11-02T02:48:00-CME-001 (see notifications 20211102-AL-001, 20211102-AL-002) and Interplanetary Shock with ID 2021-11-03T19:23:00-IPS-001 (see notification 20211103-AL-001).

NASA spacecraft at the geosynchronous orbits may be exposed to solar wind plasma and magnetic field conditions.

Activity ID: 2021-11-03T21:29:00-MPC-001.

## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate to high levels during this reporting period with 1 X-class flare and 6 M-class flares (see list below).  There were 2 O-type CMEs and 5 C-type CMEs (see details below). The X1.0 class flare peaking at 2021-10-28T15:35Z originated from Active Region 12887 and was associated with the halo O-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2021-10-28T15:53Z (details below). 

The arrival of this CME (see notifications 20211028-AL-010, 20211029-AL-001, and 20211029-AL-002 for simulation prediction results) was associated with the interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2021-10-31T09:13Z (see notification 20211031-AL-001). It was also detected by the IMPACT instrument at STEREO A around 2021-10-31T10:00Z.

The second halo O-type CME was first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2021-11-02T02:48Z and was associated with a long duration M1.6 class flare peaking at 2021-11-02T02:51Z. The O-type CME was simulated with two C-type CMEs first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2021-11-01T18:38Z (associated with a C1.3 flare which peaked at 2021-11-01T18:01Z) and 2021-11-01T21:36Z (associated with a C4.0 flare which peaked at 2021-11-01T21:33Z). It is estimated that the combined leading edge of these CMEs will reach Parker Solar Probe at 2021-11-03T06:39Z, Solar Orbiter at 2021-11-03T16:14Z, STEREO A at 2021-11-04T02:08Z, and STEREO B at 2021-11-04T00:56Z (plus minus 7 hours). The simulation also indicates that the combined leading edge of the CMEs will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2021-11-03T21:39Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notifications 20211102-AL-001 and 20211102-AL-002).

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2021-10-31T12:00Z-15:00Z. These elevated values of Kp were associated with the arrival detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2021-10-31T09:13Z of the O-type CME first detected by SOHO LASCO C2 at 2021-10-28T15:53Z described above. 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The flux of 13-100 MeV protons detected by STEREO A exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2021-10-28T16:16Z (see notifications 20211028-AL-003 and 20211028-AL-006). Also, the flux of > 100 MeV protons detected by GOES exceeded 1 pfu starting at 2021-10-28T16:35Z (see notifications 20211028-AL-004, 20211028-AL-005, and 20211028-AL-007) followed by the > 10 MeV protons exceeding the 10 pfu threshold starting at 2021-10-28T17:40Z (see notifications 20211028-AL-008 and 20211028-AL-009). The flux of one or more of the >15.8 MeV protons channels detected by SOHO were also elevated exceeding the 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2021-10-28T17:39Z. This solar energetic particle event was due to the X1.0 flare from Active Region 12887 that peaked at 2021-10-28T15:35Z and the associated O-type CME first detected by SOHO LASCO C2 at 2021-10-28T15:53Z (see notification 20211028-AL-001, 20211028-AL-002, 20211028-AL-010, 20211029-AL-001, and 20211029-AL-002).

There was a second solar energetic particle event detected by STEREO A. The flux of 13-100 MeV protons exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2021-11-01T03:12Z (see notifications 20211101-AL-001 and 20211101-AL-002). This solar energetic particle event was associated with the M1.5 class flare from Active Region 12887 that peaked at 2021-11-01T01:45Z and the associated C-type CME first detected by SOHO LASCO C2 at 2021-11-01T02:00Z.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate this week due to the solar energetic particle events described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2021-11-03T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2021-11-09T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels for the upcoming week.  There are currently six Active Regions on the Earth-facing solar disk.  Active Regions 12888 (S13W64), 12889 (S24W58), and 12892 (N26W66) have a low magnetic complexity classification and may not produce too much activity as they rotate off of the Earth-facing disk by 2021-11-06.  However, Active Region 12887 was very active during the reporting period resulting in an X-class flare, four M-class flares, one O-type CME, and the two SEP events mentioned above. It may be expected for this Active Region to produce more activity as it rotates off the Earth-facing disk early in the outlook period. Active Region 12891 (N16W24) which produced the recent M1.6 class flare and associated O-type CME may continue to produce more activity as it continues to rotate towards the limb of the Earth-facing disk throughout the outlook period. Active Region 12893 (N16e32) may continue its heightened activity throughout the outlook period.   Two new Active Regions rotated onto the STEREO A-facing disk at the end of the reporting period, and may rotate onto the Earth-facing disk near the middle of the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be between minor to moderate levels during the outlook period due to the anticipated combined arrival of the halo O-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2021-11-02T02:48Z (associated with a long duration M1.6 class flare which peaked at 2021-11-02T02:51Z) and two C-type CMEs first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2021-11-01T18:38Z (associated with a C1.3 class flare which peaked at 2021-11-01T18:01Z) and 2021-11-01T21:36Z (associated with a C4.0 class flare which peaked at 2021-11-01T21:33Z) to NASA missions near Earth at about 2021-11-03T21:39Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notifications 20211102-AL-001 and 20211102-AL-002). There is an ongoing interplanetary shock arrival detected at L1 at 2021-11-03T19:23Z that may be associated with the combined arrival of these CMEs (see notification 20211103-AL-001). The event is still ongoing at the time this report was finished.

## Summary:

Update on CME with ID 2021-11-02T02:48:00-CME-001 (see notification 20211102-AL-001) and two additional CMEs with IDs 2021-11-01T18:38:00-CME-001 and 2021-11-01T21:36:00-CME-001. Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may affect Parker Solar Probe, Solar Orbiter, STEREO A, and STEREO B. The combined leading edge of the CMEs will reach Parker Solar Probe at 2021-11-03T06:39Z, Solar Orbiter at 2021-11-03T16:14Z, STEREO A at 2021-11-04T02:08Z, and STEREO B at 2021-11-04T00:56Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CMEs may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the combined leading edge of the CMEs will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2021-11-03T21:39Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 5-7 (minor to strong).
